sample.title: Using Genetically Enhanced Plants to Naturally Extract Metals
sample.description:
Mining remains essential to the global economy, but it comes with a steep environmental cost.

Nikolaj Coster-Waldau visits Genomines, a biotech startup using genetically enhanced plants to extract metals from the ground naturally, offering a radical alternative to traditional mining.

sample.title: How Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Are Crushing Small Businesses While Big Retailers Thrive
sample.description:
Small businesses are reeling under the weight of Trump tariffs. Eunice Byun is the CEO of Material Kitchen, a small business that sells kitchenware for the home. She says the complexity of her supply chain has increased tenfold. Anjali Bhargava the owner of Anjali‚Äôs Cup which sells chai concentrate and turmeric blends says the current economic climate along with tariffs are threatening her livelihood. The U.S. has about 36 million small businesses that account for about 99.9% of all U.S. businesses. So what impact are tariffs having on small businesses and how are larger retailers like Walmart and Amazon able to skirt their impact. CNBC spoke with small business owners to find out.

2:20 - 5:55 Chapter 1 Mitigating tariffs
5:56 - 8:52 Chapter 2 Tariff impact

sample.title: A tangled web of AI deals
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence deals lately has been staggering, with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI alone racking up around $1 trillion-worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes to new highs.

But some experts are worried that this web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

sample.title: Why Americans Are Suddenly All In On Thrift Clothes
sample.description:
At ThredUp's 600,000-square-foot warehouse in Suwanee, Georgia, roughly 40,000 pieces of used clothing are processed each day. The resale company's logistics network, four facilities across the U.S., now rivals that of some fast-fashion giants. The global secondhand apparel market is expected to reach $367 billion by 2029, growing almost three times faster than the overall global apparel market. For years, Gen Z shoppers have been driving the rise of secondhand fashion. Now, rising prices and new tariffs announced by the White House earlier this year are pushing even more Americans to follow their lead. CNBC got a behind-the-scenes look at ThredUp‚Äôs operations to learn more about how new AI tools and tariffs are boosting America‚Äôs secondhand market.

00:00 Introduction
1:44 ThredUp's resale machine 
3:24 When tariffs hit fashion
5:33 AI and the future of shopping

sample.title: The Truth About AI And The Mass Layoffs
sample.description:
Between January and September 2025, there have been 946,426 job cuts announced, with roughly 300,000 from the government sector, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. But some economists don't buy that recent layoffs are caused by AI. Economic uncertainty, tariffs and less consumer spending might be hurting U.S. workers more than CEOs will admit.

1:37 Chapter 1: AI washing
3:18 Chapter 2: Cutting corporate bloat

sample.title: Are city-run grocery stores a good idea?
sample.description:
Grocery prices in U.S. urban areas have tripled over the past 40 years, straining household budgets, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic winner of New York City‚Äôs mayoral primary, is proposing city-owned grocery stores to "keep prices low, not make a profit." These are not new concepts in the U.S. and have been tried in the past.

CNBC visited two smaller cities in Kansas to see how this model operates and whether it could be replicated in larger cities.

sample.title: LIVE: Airports after Trump administration orders 10% flight cuts
sample.description:
Live coverage of travelers, airports and planes taking off at U.S. airports a day after U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said that he would order 10% of flights at 40 major U.S. airports to be cut starting Friday, November 7, unless a deal to end the federal government shutdown is reached. The cuts were expected to hit hundreds of thousands of travelers with little notice. Aviation analytics firm Cirium estimated the reductions would cancel up to 1,800 flights and cut 268,000 airline seats a day in the U.S. International flights are not affected.¬†

#us #governmentshutdown #deanduffy #airtravel #flights #shutdown #usairports #aviation #FAA #live #Reuters #News

sample.title: Have the Democrats made a comeback? | BBC Americast
sample.description:
For the first time since Donald Trump's re-election there is renewed optimism among Democrats, after Zohran Mamdani and other candidates won big. 

Alongside the win in New York and the governor races in New Jersey and West Virginia, the party also won important ‚Äì albeit less glamorous ‚Äì races in Pennsylvania and Georgia.

In this episode, Justin, Anthony and Sarah are joined by Jim Messina, a Democrat strategist and former deputy chief of staff to Barack Obama. He gives his take on what he thinks lies behind Tuesday‚Äôs wins, what he thinks the party has learned since 2024 and whether he agrees with Prop 50 - the redistricting measures passed in California to redraw the state‚Äôs political lines to favour Democrats.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: McDonald's faces new crackdown on sexual abuse. #McDonalds #BBCNews
McDonald's faces new crackdown on sexual abuse | BBC News
sample.description:
McDonald's will bring in new sexual harassment training for managers in strengthened measures agreed with the equality watchdog to protect its staff from abuse.

The move was "in response to serious allegations raised", the watchdog said, after it initially intervened in the company.

A BBC investigation two years ago was told that workers, some as young as 17, were being groped and harassed. 

Earlier this year, McDonald's staff told us they still faced sexual abuse and harassment.

McDonald's said it welcomed the new measures, adding that they would "build on the significant progress we have already made in this space".

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Stephen Fry and the Godfather of AI | BBC News
sample.description:
Sir Stephen Fry, actor, comedian and recent star of 'Celebrity Traitors', joins the renowned Canadian computer scientist and 'Godfather of AI' Yoshua Bengio.
 
They discuss their shared concern about the development of advanced AI systems. Does the world need a red telephone, as introduced in the nuclear era? What are the dangers of people forming emotional attachments with machines? And where do the solutions lie?
 
This week presenter Christian Fraser is joined by regular host Dr Stephanie Hare.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
